turns.content: How does an airplane's engine work and what fuel is used to keep it running?

An airplane's engine works by using the combustion of fuel to turn a series of turbines that rotate the propellers or fan blades responsible for thrust. There are two types of airplane engines: piston engines and turbine engines. Piston engines operate similar to those found in cars: fuel is ignited in a cylinder of the engine, pushing a piston up and down, which turns the engine's crankshaft. Turbine engines work differently: they have a compressor that compresses air, a combustion chamber where fuel is ignited to heat the compressed air, and a mixture of hot air and gases that exits the engine, spinning a turbine and powering the plane. 

Jet fuel, also known as aviation turbine fuel (ATF), is used to keep airplane engines running. Jet fuel is a type of kerosene that has been refined to meet the specific needs of aviation. It has a high-energy density, allowing it to provide more energy per gallon than other types of fuel, making it ideal for powering airplanes. Additionally, jet fuel has a low freezing point, so it will not solidify at high altitudes where temperatures are very low. This is necessary to ensure that the engine has a constant flow of fuel at all times.

Sure, I can give you a quick overview of the differences between piston and turbine engines in terms of performance and efficiency. 

One of the main differences is that turbine engines are generally more powerful than piston engines. Turbine engines can produce a lot of power for their size and weight, making them ideal for larger commercial airplanes that need to carry a lot of passengers and cargo. Piston engines, on the other hand, are better suited for smaller aircraft or private planes.

Another difference is that turbine engines are generally more fuel-efficient than piston engines. This is because turbine engines can extract more energy from the fuel they burn, and they also have a higher compression ratio, which helps to increase their efficiency. Piston engines are typically less efficient, though they are often more reliable and require less maintenance.

Finally, turbine engines are generally quieter than piston engines, which can be important for reducing noise pollution in populated areas. This is because turbine engines operate at much higher speeds than piston engines, which produces a more consistent and smooth sound. Piston engines, on the other hand, produce a more irregular sound that can be louder and more disruptive.

Yes, there are a few more differences that set the two engine types apart. For example, piston engines are typically simpler in design and operation compared to turbine engines, which can make them easier to operate and maintain. Piston engines use a spark plug to ignite the fuel in the cylinder, which is similar to how gasoline engines in cars work. On the other hand, turbine engines have a more complex design that requires more specialized expertise to operate and maintain.

Another difference is that piston engines can use a wider variety of fuels, including gasoline, ethanol, and diesel, while turbine engines typically run on jet fuel, which is a specialized type of kerosene. This is because turbine engines require a very specific type of fuel that is formulated for high-altitude, high-speed flight.

Finally, the way that the two engine types produce their power is different as well. Piston engines produce power in a series of small explosions, while turbine engines produce a continuous flow of power that is more steady and efficient. This is one of the reasons why turbine engines are better suited for powering larger commercial airplanes that need to maintain a high speed and altitude for extended periods of time.
